prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: COSMOS observations
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
These are Band-7 continuum observations of z ~ 2 star-forming galaxies with CO from independent observations in the PHIBSS1/2 IRAM surveys. We request a compact array configuration so that, at 1.1 arcsec resolution, the sources are effectively point sources.
The fluxes of these COSMOS sources are now based on the initial ALMA Cycle 2 observations.
To minimize overheads, we have grouped objects in the same field and with similar expected flux levels into Science Goals, setting the exposure time for the expected faintest (except for a single source at about 0.1 mJy where we will accept a lower S/N).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our Cycle 2 program was based on estimated f_850 flux densities derived from an empirical Herschel-based average SED. As described in the text, we now know from the existing Cycle 2 data on these COSMOS sources, that this is a significant over-estimate and that most sources have f_850 in the 0.2-0.3 mJy range. Accordingly, we have modified the expected flux densities in COSMOS to reflect the actual Cycle-2 detections. The goal of these observations is to yield a minimum detection significance of 4-6 sigma for almost all the sources. We therefore set the nominal sensitivity to 50 micro-Jy, accepting that we will likely get a lower S/N on a single source that appears to have about 0.1 Jy flux density.
This is a continuum observation so the correlator setup should be standard
We do not want to significantly resolve these high redshift galaxies which will have an angular extent of about 1 arcsec.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Q1623 observations
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
These are Band-7 continuum observations of z ~ 2 star-forming galaxies with CO from independent observations in the PHIBSS1/2 IRAM surveys. We request a compact array configuration so that, at 1.1 arcsec resolution, the sources are effectively point sources.
We have estimated the expected spectra energy distributions from the average Herschel-based SED(SFR,m,z) of Magnelli et al (2013), but "corrected" for the mean discrepancy between these predictions and the Cycle 2 observations in the COSMOS field.
To minimize overheadss, we have grouped objects in the same field and with similar expected flux levels into Science Goals, setting the exposure time for the expected faintest.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our Cycle 2 program was based on estimated f_850 flux densities derived from an empirical Herschel-based average SED. As described in the text, we now know from the existing Cycle 2 data on the COSMOS sources, that this is a significant over-estimate and that most sources will likely have f_850 in the 0.2-0.3 mJy range. Accordingly, we have modified the expected flux densities in the remaining fields. The goal of these observations is to yield a minimum detection significance of 4-6 sigma for almost all the sources. We therefore set the nominal sensitivity to 60 micro-Jy since the faintest new flux density prediction is 0.25 mJy.
This is a continuum observation so the correlator setup should be standard
We do not want to significantly resolve these high redshift galaxies

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Q2343 bright source observations
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
These are Band-7 continuum observations of z ~ 2 star-forming galaxies with CO from independent observations in the PHIBSS1/2 IRAM surveys. We request a compact array configuration so that, at 11 arcsec resolution, the sources are effectively point sources.
We have estimated the expected spectra energy distributions from the average Herschel-based SED(SFR,m,z) of Magnelli et al (2013) but now corrected for the discrepancy seen between these predictions and the Cycle 2 observations in the COSMOS field.
To minimize overheads, we have grouped objects in the same field and with similar expected flux levels into Science Goals, setting the exposure time for the expected faintest.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our Cycle 2 program was based on estimated f_850 flux densities derived from an empirical Herschel-based average SED. As described in the text, we now know from the existing Cycle 2 data on the COSMOS sources, that this is a significant over-estimate and that most sources will likely have f_850 in the 0.2-0.3 mJy range. Accordingly, we have modified the expected flux densities in the remaining fields. The goal of these observations is to yield a minimum detection significance of 4-6 sigma for almost all the sources. We therefore set the nominal sensitivity to 75 micro-Jy because the faintest new flux density prediction is 0.4 mJy.
This is a continuum observation so the correlator setup should be standard
We do not want to significantly resolve these high redshift galaxies

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Q2343 faint source observations
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
These are Band-7 continuum observations of z ~ 2 star-forming galaxies with CO from independent observations in the PHIBSS1/2 IRAM surveys. We request a compact array configuration so that, at 11 arcsec resolution, the sources are effectively point sources.
We have estimated the expected spectra energy distributions from the average Herschel-based SED(SFR,m,z) of Magnelli et al (2013) but now corrected for the offset between these predictions and our Cycle 2 observations in the COSMOS field.
To minimize overheadss, we have grouped objects in the same field and with similar expected flux levels into Science Goals, setting the exposure time for the expected faintest.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our Cycle 2 program was based on estimated f_850 flux densities derived from an empirical Herschel-based average SED. As described in the text, we now know from the existing Cycle 2 data on the COSMOS sources, that this is a significant over-estimate and that most sources will likely have f_850 in the 0.2-0.3 mJy range. Accordingly, we have modified the expected flux densities in the remaining fields. The goal of these observations is to yield a minimum detection significance of 4-6 sigma for almost all the sources. We therefore set the nominal sensitivity to 30 micro-Jy because the faintest new predicted flux density is 0.12 Jy.
This is a continuum observation so the correlator setup should be standard
We do not want to significantly resolve these high redshift galaxies

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: D3-6004 and 15504
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
These are Band-7 continuum observations of z ~ 2 star-forming galaxies with CO from independent observations in the PHIBSS1/2 IRAM surveys. We request a compact array configuration so that, at 11 arcsec resolution, the sources are effectively point sources.
We have estimated the expected spectra energy distributions from the average Herschel-based SED(SFR,m,z) of Magnelli et al (2013), but now corrected for the offset between these predictions and our Cycle 2 observations in the COSMOS field.
To minimize overheads, we have grouped objects in the same field and with similar expected flux levels into Science Goals, setting the exposure time for the expected faintest.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our Cycle 2 program was based on estimated f_850 flux densities derived from an empirical Herschel-based average SED. As described in the text, we now know from the existing Cycle 2 data on the COSMOS sources, that this is a significant over-estimate and that most sources will likely have f_850 in the 0.2-0.3 mJy range. Accordingly, we have modified the expected flux densities in the remaining fields. The goal of these observations is to yield a minimum detection significance of 4-6 sigma for almost all the sources. The faintest predicted flux in this field is now 0.5 mJy. We set the nominal sensitivity to 50 micro-Jy, since otherwise we are dominated by overheads for two sources.
This is a continuum observation so the set up should be standard
We do not want to significantly resolve these high redshift galaxies.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We are undertaking a systematic multi-parameter study of gas and dust in normal star-forming galaxies at high z with the goal of understanding the processes that regulate their star-formation rates across cosmic time. We are obtaining CO measurements and other diagnostics including star-formation rates, gas metallicities and reddening, gas kinematics and outflow rates for a total of more than 200 galaxies spread in mass, SFR and z. In Cycle 2, we were awarded ALMA observing time to secure 850 micron measurements of the total dust mass in 28 z > 2 Main Sequence galaxies. These observations are progressing well, but it is already apparent that the galaxies are significantly fainter than we had predicted from empirical Herschel SED templates. This could be due to a number of causes, including those linked to the lower metallicties of these galaxies, which further motivates the systematic and comprehensive approach that we are following. However, it does also mean that we need to increase the integration time to convert the many 2-3 sigma detections (which we know are real from stacking) into usable measurements. This is the focus of the current proposal.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
